Hello, I think there are some prizes in the shop that makes sense but some would be a great addition to the shop.

One of that is a great educational and design code related to animations on the website by <https://x.com/emilkowalski_|Emil Kowalski>. The website <http://animations.dev|animations.dev> in itself describes the course and what it's benefits are. If we need to buy this alone this course is only available for 10 days from 14 Jan to 24 January but it can be bought up for a team or an org anytime of the season.

• There is also student discount (20 %).  
• Certificate of completion
• Purchasing Power Parity to avoid heavy fees
• Future updates are all free 
• Beginner Friendly
• Certificate of Achievement (Verifiable) 
As compared to some bad options like the lockpick, hackclub socks ( No offence intended they are good too) and some good options like Zines by Julia Evans , Github Pins and Factorio Game this is a great choice.

Note that this is not a promotion of the course or something but as i told i have been waiting to buy this for months as it is only available for some particular days in a quarter of the year, I follow Emil personally on X and you may also have used some of the components that he have created maybe in IOS / React / Nextjs or in Vanilla JavaScript and Framer Motion.

It could be the best gift for me this Christmas and New Year and believe me you will thank me for this later.

I think we need the Mac Mini M4(16GB RAM, 256GB Storage) in the shop. It's $599 but since we're all students, we can probably get it for $499. And the best part is, it's incredibly versatile. It can be used for schoolwork, coding, editing, and much more. It can run Xcode, which is particularly useful for creating apps for the apple ecosystem. If necessary, it could even run a relatively fast Windows VM, which would allow students to get the best of both operating systems. There is clear need for this item - <https://hackclub.slack.com/archives/C07443MC9UP/p1731168551787859|a poll from November> showed the need for the device - 20% of voters said they would find the Mac Mini M4 useful. Besides, the Mac Mini is a realistic alternative to the Macbook Air, which only has an 8 core CPU and GPU, unlike the mini's 10 core CPU and GPU. The Mini, which starts at 16GB Ram, is much stronger and more affordable than most windows counterparts. In conclusion, the Mac Mini's versatility, pricing, and speed are all factors that draw a single conclusion - that the Mac Mini would be one of the most needed items in the whole High Seas store.

PS: If you agree, go upvote the Mac Mini on the poll!

My pitch to hackclub:

Although the framework and MacBook are both highly capable laptops, they require extremely high amounts of doubloons which for most people is unobtainable, due to many factors, a big one being time constraints due to school work.

Therefore, a less expensive but still reasonably performant option is needed. Refurbished thinkpads would fit this role perfectly. They are renowned for their reliability and are especially popular among Linux users, in part due to the sleek and traditional ThinkPad aesthetic and build quality (see:

Adding some more information because it seems that's good:

I don't have the pixel watch 2, but as far as I can see, it's a great smartwatch with performant hardware with support for Google's WearOs 5, the latest version of WearOs, meaning it's got the latest SDK level so apps can be developed and tested for the latest software. It's based on android so it's a well documented, standardised and widespread platform which many developers will be familiar with. Apps can be published to the play store similar to normal android apps, so it would pair well with the upcoming <#C07N06B1FDY|> if it is added to the high seas shop.

Not only is it great for development, but it's also a brilliant everyday watch, despite the admittedly rather pitiful battery life (around 24 hours with AOD, although it's better than the original pixel watch and is apparently further improved with WearOs 5). It has very accurate activity tracking and has a smooth, clean and intuitive interface, with a wide range of watch faces made by Google and by other developers, with the ability to code new faces and publish them. It has the option for always on display, meaning that the time can always be seen without having to do weird gestures or manually tap it (flashbacks to Fitbit alta). It also, in my humble opinion, looks really nice, and cases and straps are widely available for it to make it look unique.

Overall, the pixel watch 2 (or even the 3 if hackclub's feeling fancy) would clearly be a brilliant addition to the shop!

_*what would i do over the summer?*_ for me, this question is about what i want to accomplish before the end of my gap year here at hq, since my last day is aug 30 (how do i feel about this? :/ but also excited for the future, as i need a change of scenery)
• four ysws (three more to go) that run well before the end of my gap year. a ysws that runs well means that it teaches hack clubbers how to do something that seems technically daunting, and that is/was technically daunting for me too. it makes them feel like wizards. learning has always mattered more than this to me, but quantitatively, more than 20 ships each. ideas so far: graphics/ai ;)
• learn low level programming really well - ship a few projects in rust/c, like a wakatime/ngrok/git/docker clone. go through <https://cryptopals.com/|cryptopals>
• ship [redacted] - a personal very large scope meaningful project that i talked to <@U041FQB8VK2> about at one point because i want to ship something useful to me outside of "hq work". _more importantly - figure out how to juggle this with hq work._
• prepare to move to sf! get rid of all my things (challenge: try and sell as much as i can), save for a single carry on bag. take a train across the country. and of course, the tradition.
